item.title: Britain to Finish Returning Citizens From Sharm el Sheikh by End of Weekend
item.description: This month, the country suspended all flights in and out of the city in response to security concerns that a bomb might have brought down a Russian jetliner.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Bodies of 7 Babies Are Found in Bavaria
item.description: The police were summoned on Thursday to the town of Wallenfels, a spokesman said, after a woman called an emergency doctor after discovering what appeared to be body parts.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Front-Page Warning for China’s Party Cadres: Buy the Paper, or Else
item.description: An article in Harbin Daily told party officials that subscribing to party publications was “an important political task,” and it warned that foot-draggers would be publicly named and shamed.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO
item.media:description: A man reading a newspaper while waiting at a bicycle repair shop in Beijing.

item.title: Outcome of Airstrike Targeting ‘Jihadi John’ Is Unknown, Kerry and Cameron Say
item.description: The two officials spoke, in separate briefings, the morning after the Pentagon confirmed that the attack had been aimed at the Islamic State’s most notorious executioner.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain called Mohammed Emwazi a “serious and ongoing threat to innocent civilians not only in Syria, but around the world and in the United Kingdom, too.”

item.title: Australia Defends Port’s Lease to Chinese Company With Military Ties
item.description: The territorial leader has backed the company’s lease in Darwin after a research institute said it could be used to spy on American Marines based there.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ezra F. Vogel on China’s Shifting Relations With Japan and Taiwan
item.description: Dispirited by mounting tensions between the two countries, Mr. Vogel, a Harvard sociologist, has set out to promote a deeper understanding of their relationship across time.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Kurds Enter Sinjar in Bid to Retake It From Islamic State
item.description: Having cut an important supply road east and west of the city, competing units from two Kurdish groups fought their way into its center.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish forces moving through Mount Sinjar on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Organ Transplants Suffer Amid China’s Transportation Delays
item.description: Unlike many developed nations, the country does not have dedicated organ transport systems and doctors must rely on commercial means.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Dr. Chen Jingyu, second from left, and other surgeons performing a lung transplant.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Claims of Corruption Chip Away at Trust in Sports
item.description: Questions of doping and corruption have spread to those in high office at the International Association of Athletics Federations.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Sebastian Coe, the president of the International Association of Athletics Federations and an Olympic medalist, has promised to confront claims of corruption leveled against his organization “without fear or favor.”

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Europe Mislabels Israel
item.description: The European Union’s latest attempt to strike back at Israel by relabeling Israeli products is not only unfair, it’s illegal.
item.dc:creator: EUGENE KONTOROVICH

item.title: Myanmar Election Panel Says Aung San Suu Kyi’s Party Won Majority
item.description: News that the National League for Democracy had taken 348 seats in Parliament reinforces a rout of the military-backed ruling party in a landmark election.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: After Shift in One-Child Policy, Regret in China’s ‘Loneliest Generation’
item.description: For the millions who grew up as only children, the Communist Party’s move to allow married couples to have two offspring reawakened feelings of isolation.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Like many from the one-child generation, Liu Jia, 27, is struggling to decide whether to have a second child. “I can’t give my son a sibling, it’s too expensive,” she said.

item.title: Pentagon Says It Targeted ‘Jihadi John’
item.description: The military is assessing whether Mohammed Emwazi, considered the most prominent British member of the Islamic State, was killed in a strike near Raqqa, Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Abdul Karim al-Eryani, Yemeni Politician Who Brokered Arab Spring Peace, Dies at 81
item.description: A former prime minister and diplomat, Mr. Eryani helped bring about a peaceful change of government in 2011.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: EVA SOHLMAN
item.media:description: Abdul Karim al-Eryani addressed a United Nations news conference in 1994.

item.title: Report Ties Kenyan Army to Militants’ Smuggling
item.description: The report by a Kenyan watchdog group accuses the Kenyan military of making money on smuggling alongside the Shabab Islamist militants in Somalia.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: Kenyan and Somali troops in 2011 amid charcoal in Somalia that had been controlled by militants who used it for revenue.

item.title: Coordinated European Raids Target Ring Supporting Terrorist Groups
item.description: The authorities arrested 15 people in four countries believed to be seeking to overthrow the Kurdish government in northern Iraq and to recruit Islamic State militants.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: The Iraqi Kurdish cleric Najmuddin Faraj Ahmad, also known as Mullah Krekar, in Oslo in August.

item.title: U.S. Steps Up Its Attacks on ISIS-Controlled Oil Fields in Syria
item.description: Frustrated by ISIS militants’ ability to keep producing oil despite airstrikes against refineries, the United States has moved to inflict damage that takes longer to fix.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A United States Air Force F-15E Strike Eagle on Thursday in Lakenheath, England, before operations over Iraq and Syria.

item.title: World Briefing: Romania: Fire’s Death Toll Increases
item.description: Two more people have died of burns sustained in a nightclub fire last month in Bucharest, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: John Kerry Tempers Expectations for Syria Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry indicated Thursday that there was a vast gulf among world leaders on the future of the Syrian president, but a shared commitment to defeating the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Iran President Doesn’t Rule Out Normalized U.S. Ties One Day
item.description: The Iranian president’s remarks, in an interview with an Italian newspaper, appeared at odds with those of Iran’s supreme leader, at least in tone.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
